misconceptions.name: Implemented average acceleration instead of summing even integers
misconceptions.description: The program solves a physics-style average acceleration problem using v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers, filtering the even ones, and summing them as required by the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that Q1 is asking them to read v0, v1, and t and compute the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q1 requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking which of them are even (n % 2 == 0), accumulating the sum of those even numbers, and then printing that sum.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers.
Reads three double values using nextDouble rather than five integers.
Computes acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t instead of any sum.
No loop structure to process 5 inputs.
No conditional check for even numbers.
Output message is "The average acceleration is ..." rather than "Sum of even numbers: ...".
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this problem and a different textbook/example exercise about average acceleration, or reuse of starter code from another question without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ignore the acceleration template and rewrite the program directly from the problem description: use a loop that runs 5 times, read an int each time, check if it is even with n % 2 == 0, add even numbers to a running sum, and finally print "Sum of even numbers: " followed by the sum.
related_concepts: Algorithm design for simple input-processing tasks
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompt text, and the core formula exactly match a standard acceleration example and are completely unrelated to summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: This block reads three doubles v0, v1, t, computes (v1 - v0) / t, and prints an acceleration message, which does not match the required behavior of summing even numbers among 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Using double inputs where integers are specified
misconceptions.description: The program uses double variables and nextDouble() for user input even though the problem specifies reading 5 integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to treat all numeric keyboard input as doubles, even when the problem explicitly asks for integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifies integer input, int variables and nextInt() (or equivalent) should normally be used. While doubles can represent many integers exactly, choosing the appropriate data type improves clarity and prevents subtle type-related issues.
symptoms: Uses double v0, v1, t instead of int variables for an integer-input task.
Calls input.nextDouble() instead of input.nextInt().
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely habit of defaulting to double for numeric values or copying from a previous example that used doubles, without adjusting to the new problem's integer requirement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Match your variable types and Scanner methods to the problem specification: use int and nextInt() when the task calls for integers, and double and nextDouble() when real numbers are required.
related_concepts: Scanner methods for different data types
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The use of doubles and nextDouble() is consistent with a copied acceleration example, so this may be template reuse rather than a deep misunderstanding, but it still conflicts with the requirement for integers.

evidence.note: All three inputs are read as doubles instead of the integers requested in the problem statement.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Implementation (Acceleration calculation)
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a solution for a different problem (calculating average acceleration from initial velocity, final velocity, and time) instead of solving the assigned problem (calculating the sum of five even integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for a physics acceleration problem, possibly mistaking the assignment or having a file mix-up. They are not attempting the assignment's core requirements.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading five integers, checking each for evenness, and accumulating the sum of only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code bears no resemblance to the required solution structure (loops, conditionals, integer input).
The code uses floating-point types (double).
It prompts for and calculates acceleration.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of the assignment requirements or gross file mix-up/copy-paste error, resulting in a solution to an unrelated problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the problem statement (Q1. Sum of Even Numbers) carefully and write a new program that reads five integers, checks which ones are even, and calculates their sum. The current code solves for average acceleration, which is not what was asked.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code's prompt, variable names (v0, v1, t), and calculation are undeniably for a different, distinct problem (acceleration calculation).

evidence.note: The class name suggests a different problem is being solved.
The input variables (v0, v1, t) and type (double) are incorrect for the required problem (5 integers).
The core logic computes acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage (Double instead of int)
misconceptions.description: The student uses 'double' to read and process input, while the problem explicitly requires reading and processing 'integers'.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to rely on floating-point numbers when integers are necessary, possibly stemming from the completely wrong problem they chose to implement (acceleration typically involves doubles).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem asks for '5 integers', which should be handled using the `int` data type in Java, and read using `input.nextInt()`. Using doubles makes checking for evenness (modulo operation `% 2`) incorrect or more complex than necessary.
symptoms: Use of `double` declaration and `nextDouble()` method.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student focused on a physics problem that typically requires floating-point arithmetic rather than the assignment's explicit requirement for integer math.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure that the correct primitive data types (e.g., `int` for integers) are used when reading and processing numerical input as specified by the problem. The correct method for reading integers is `input.nextInt()`.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as the problem clearly calls for integers, but the student exclusively uses doubles.

evidence.note: Three doubles are read instead of five integers.

evidence.snippet: double acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t; // hope no divide by zero
evidence.note: The variable used for calculation is also a double.

misconceptions.name: Wrong Problem Submission
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem (physics acceleration calculation) instead of the assigned sum-of-even-numbers problem. The code reads 3 doubles and computes (v1 - v0) / t instead of reading 5 integers and filtering for even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics acceleration problem involving velocity and time calculations.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers from the user, checking each for evenness using the modulo operator (n % 2 == 0), accumulating only the even values, and printing the sum in the format 'Sum of even numbers: X'.
symptoms: Code reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
Output displays acceleration formula result instead of sum of evens
Program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of requesting 5 integers
Uses double data type instead of int
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely a copy-paste error, file mix-up, or severe misreading of the assignment. The student submitted code from a different problem entirely.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify you are solving the correct problem. Re-read the assignment: 'Write a program that reads 5 integers from the user and prints the sum of only the even numbers.' Start fresh with a loop to read 5 integers, use an if statement with (num % 2 == 0) to filter evens, accumulate the sum, and print the result.
related_concepts: Reading multiple integers in a loop
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is unmistakably solving a different problem (physics acceleration) with completely different variable names, formula, logic, input count, data types, and output. This is not a misconception but a fundamental submission error.

evidence.note: Reads 3 doubles with physics variable names instead of 5 integers for even-sum problem
Computes acceleration using physics formula instead of summing even numbers
Outputs acceleration result instead of sum of even numbers in required format

misconceptions.name: Implemented average acceleration calculation instead of summing even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program solves a different physics-style problem (average acceleration from v0, v1, and t) instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even numbers as required. It reads three doubles, performs a single arithmetic computation, and prints an acceleration message, with no loop, no even check, and no accumulator for the sum.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a program which reads v0, v1, and t and computes (v1 - v0) / t is an acceptable solution for this question.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop to process them, check each number with n % 2 == 0 to see if it is even, accumulate the sum of the even numbers only, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Program prompts for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers
Uses nextDouble() to read three values instead of nextInt() for five integers
Computes acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t rather than summing selected inputs
No loop is used to process multiple inputs
No conditional check for even numbers (no use of n % 2 == 0)
Output message is "The average acceleration is ..." instead of "Sum of even numbers: ..."
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook/exercise problems or reuse of a template for an average-acceleration problem instead of implementing the required sum-of-evens algorithm.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and design the algorithm to match it: (1) read 5 integers, preferably using a loop; (2) inside the loop, use n % 2 == 0 to test for even numbers; (3) add only the even numbers to a running total; (4) print the final sum with the required message.
related_concepts: Using loops to handle repeated input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, arithmetic formula, output message) corresponds to an average-acceleration exercise and none of it matches the required sum-of-even-numbers task.

evidence.note: This code reads three doubles for v0, v1, and t, computes (v1 - v0) / t, and prints an acceleration message. It never reads 5 integers, never checks for even numbers, and never sums them, so it implements a different problem than the one assigned.

Code reads 3 doubles, not 5 integers
